formats.name: mini_manifesto
formats.instruction: Declare your core belief about a specific issue in one bold sentence. Add a single, vivid metaphor or analogy to drive it home. Keep it under 30 words.

formats.name: reverse_advice
formats.instruction: Describe a popular strategy for solving a problem, then explain why doing the opposite sometimes works better. End with a quirky ‘try this instead’ suggestion. 150-250 words.

formats.name: micro_drama
formats.instruction: Write a tiny fictional scene (2-3 lines), set in your topic’s world, showing a conflict or turning point. Close with a comment on what lesson the scene offers. 40-80 words.

formats.name: question_chain
formats.instruction: Start with a big question related to your topic, then layer 3-5 increasingly granular or quirky follow-up questions. Finish with a challenge: ‘Dare to answer them all.’ 60-120 words.

formats.name: data_daydream
formats.instruction: Imagine a dataset about your topic that doesn’t exist, describe at least three wild findings you’d expect to see, and speculate how the world would change. 200-350 words.

formats.name: contrarian_listicle
formats.instruction: List 4-6 common ‘truths’ about your topic, then briefly debunk each with a twist. Use bullet points, stay snappy, and inject humor. Keep it under 150 words.

formats.name: epic_origin_story
formats.instruction: Narrate how something in your topic’s world began, blending fact and playful fiction. Use narrative momentum, surprising turns, and vivid details. 300-500 words.

formats.name: sensory_explainer
formats.instruction: Explain your topic entirely through sensations—describe sights, sounds, tastes, smells, and feelings that characterize it. No abstract concepts allowed. 100-200 words.

formats.name: prophecy_post
formats.instruction: Write from the perspective of a future expert looking back on the present moment. Predict how your topic will evolve and what will surprise everyone. 200-400 words.

title_styles: Write a playful title that teases the reader. Examples: 'Can You Handle the Truth About X?', 'Guess What Happens If You Try Y?'
Write a poetic metaphor title. Examples: 'X Is the Secret Sauce We Forgot', 'Y is a Ship Adrift in a Sea of Z'
Write a declarative title that predicts the future. Examples: 'Why X Will Soon Be Obsolete', 'The Next Big Shift: Y Will Change Everything'
Write a provocative title that promises a twist. Examples: 'Everything You Know About X Is Backwards', 'The Hidden Cost of Y Nobody Talks About'
structure_variants: Open with an unexpected analogy, then weave it into every argument.
Alternate between your main points and real-life examples in each paragraph.
Conclude with a whimsical call to action that borders on the absurd.
Embed facts or stats within an ongoing narrative instead of listing them.
Use rapid-fire Q&A format for each subtopic.
topic_angles: Explore how technology changes ancient traditions.
Investigate the psychology behind everyday habits.
Unpack the economic ripple effects of new gadgets.
Examine how misinformation spreads and survives.
Reveal hidden environmental impacts in daily routines.
